revision.text:
{{too technical|date=June 2017}}
'''ICAD''' (Corporate history: ICAD, Inc., Concentra (name change at IPO in 1995), KTI (name change in 1998), Dassault Systemes (purchase in 2001) (<ref>[http://www.ds-kti.com/our_products/icad.shtml The ICAD System] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041122204622/http://www.ds-kti.com/our_products/icad.shtml |date=November 22, 2004}}</ref>) is a [[knowledge-based engineering]] (KBE) system that enables users to encode design knowledge using a semantic representation that can be evaluated for [[Parasolid]] output. ICAD has an open architecture that can utilize all the power and flexibility of the underlying language.
KBE, as implemented via ICAD, received a lot of attention due to the remarkable results that appeared to take little effort.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} ICAD allowed one example of [[end-user computing]] that in a sense is unparalleled. Most ICAD developers were degreed engineers. Systems developed by ICAD users were non-trivial and consisted of highly complicated code. In the sense of [[end-user computing]], ICAD was the first to allow the power of a domain tool to be in the hands of the user, at the same time being open to allow extensions as identified and defined by the domain expert or [[subject-matter expert]] (SME).{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}}
A COE article<ref>{{cite web|last1=Switlik |first1=John |title=Knowledge Based Engineering (KBE): Update |url=http://legacy.coe.org/newsnet/Oct05/index.cfm |website=coe.org |publisher=COE |access-date=6 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324223121/http://legacy.coe.org/newsnet/Oct05/index.cfm |archive-date=24 March 2012 |date=October–November 2005 |dead-url=unfit}}</ref> looked at the resulting explosion of expectations (see [[AI winter]]), which were not sustainable. However, such a bubble burst does not diminish the existence of ability that would exist were expectations and use reasonable or properly managed.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
==History== The original implementation of ICAD was on a [[Lisp machine]] ([[Symbolics]]). Some of the principals involved with the development were Larry Rosenfeld,<ref name="glengaryllc">{{cite web |url=http://www.glengaryllc.com/Our-Team/Partner-Directory.aspx?id=22 |publisher=glengaryllc.com |title=Welcome to Glengary LLC – Partner Directory | Larry Rosenfeld, ICAD Founder |access-date=11 April 2017}}</ref> Avrum Belzer, Patrick M. O'Keefe, Philip Greenspun, and David F. Place. The time frame was 1984–85.<ref>[[Philip Greenspun]]'s [http://philip.greenspun.com/narcissism/resume resume]</ref><ref>[[Philip Greenspun]]'s List of [http://philip.greenspun.com/narcissism/resume-list Engineering Projects]</ref>
ICAD started on special-purpose Symbolics Lisp hardware and was then ported to [[Unix]] when [[Common Lisp]] became portable to general-purpose workstations.
The original domain for ICAD was [[Mechanical engineering|mechanical design]] with many application successes. However, ICAD has found use in other domains, such as [[Electrical engineering|electrical design]], shape modeling, etc. An example project could be wind tunnel design or the development of a support tool for aircraft multidisciplinary design.<ref>Bermell-Garcia, P. et al () [http://www.gid.uji.es/sites/default/files/congresos/2006_ant/A%20KBE%20System%20for%20the%20design%20of%20wind%20tunnel%20models%20using%20reusable%20knowledge%20components.pdf A KBE System for the design of wind tunnel models using reusable knowledge components]</ref><ref name="tudelft">{{cite web |url=http://www.lr.tudelft.nl/live/pagina.jsp?id=f1030549-cee5-4197-a4b0-2197fe671949&lang=en&binary=/doc/KBEtoFEmodelGen-Rocca.pdf |publisher=lr.tudelft.nl |title=A modular reconfigurable software tool to support distributed multidisciplinary design and optimization of complex products |access-date=11 April 2017}}{{dead link |date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref><ref>[http://www.stanleyknutson.com/kbe-history.html Stanley Knutson], ICAD Chief Scientist</ref> Further examples can be found in the presentations at the annual IIUG (International ICAD Users Group) that have been published in the [http://www.ds-kti.com/the_kti_vault/events.shtml KTI Vault]{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} (1999 through 2002).<ref name="tudelft2">{{cite web|url=http://www.lr.tudelft.nl/live/pagina.jsp?id=f1030549-cee5-4197-a4b0-2197fe671949&lang=en&binary=/doc/2002_5447-Gianfranco.pdf|publisher=lr.tudelft.nl|title=The last ICAD application to receive the KBE Innovation Award at the 2002 IIUG conference in Boston |access-date=11 April 2017}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> Boeing and Airbus used ICAD extensively to develop various components in the 1990s and early 21st century.
As of 2003, ICAD was featured strongly in several areas as evidenced by the [http://www.ds-kti.com/the_kti_vault/2002_ppt/Product-Vision-and-Roadmap-Overview-for-IIUG-2002.ppt Vision & Strategy Product Vision and Strategy]{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} presentation. After 2003, ICAD use diminished. At the end of 2001, the KTI Company faced financial difficulties and laid off most of its best staff. They were eventually bought out by Dassault who effectively scuppered the ICAD product. See [https://web.archive.org/web/20060619194319/http://www.coe.org/newsnet/may03/icadnews.cfm IIUG at COE, 2003] (first meeting due to Dassault by KTI)
The ICAD system was very expensive, relatively, and was in the price range of high-end systems. Market dynamics couldn't support this as there may not have been sufficient differentiating factors between ICAD and the lower-end systems (or the promises from Dassault). KTI was absorbed by Dassault Systemes and ICAD is no longer considered the go-forward tool for knowledge-based engineering (KBE) applications by that company. Dassault Systemes is promoting a suite of tools oriented around version 5 of their popular CATIA CAD application, with Knowledgeware the replacement for ICAD.
{{As of|2005}}, things were still a bit unclear. [https://web.archive.org/web/20050205213112/http://ds-kti.com/latest_news/index.shtml ICAD 8.3] was delivered. The recent COE Aerospace Conference had a discussion about the futures of KBE. One issue involves the stacking of 'meta' issues within a computer model. How this is resolved, whether by more icons or the availability of an external language, remains to be seen.
The [http://www.genworks.com Genworks GDL] product (including kernel technology from [https://github.com/genworks/gendl the Gendl Project]) is the nearest functional equivalent to ICAD currently available.
==Particulars== ICAD provided a declarative language (IDL) using New [[Flavors (programming language)|Flavors]] (never converted to [[Common Lisp Object System]] (CLOS)) that supported a mechanism for relating parts (defpart) via a hierarchical set of relationships. Technically, the ICAD Defpart was a [[Lisp (programming language)|Lisp]] macro; the ICAD defpart list was a set of generic classes that can be instantiated with specific properties depending upon what was represented. This defpart list was extendible via composited parts that represented domain entities. Along with the part-subpart relations, ICAD supported generic relations via the object modeling abilities of Lisp.
Example applications of ICAD range from a small collection of defparts that represents a part or component to a larger collection that represents an assembly. In terms of power, an ICAD system, when fully specified, can generate thousands of instances of parts on a major assembly design.
One example of an application driving thousands of instances of parts is that of an aircraft wing – where fastener type and placement may number in the thousands, each instance requiring evaluation of several factors driving the design parameters.
==Futures (KBE, etc.)== One role for ICAD may be serving as the defining prototype for KBE which would require that we know more about what occurred the past 15 years (much information is tied up behind corporate firewalls and under proprietary walls). With the rise of [[functional programming]] languages (an example is [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]]) in the markets, perhaps some of the power attributable to [[Lisp (programming language)|Lisp]] may be replicated.
==See also== *[[Functional programming]] *[[Knowledge-based systems]] *[[Orphaned technology]] *[[Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, Delft University of Technology]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071026193646/http://www.coe.org/coldfusion/newsnet/june03/implementation.cfm#1 ICAD Surfacing Project—Switlik, J.M. Geometric/Knowledge Modeling Challenges] *[http://www.lr.tudelft.nl/live/pagina.jsp?id=b5411c30-06d3-424a-849b-085b774687c5&lang=en Research group that used to work with ICAD: Systems Engineering and Aircraft Design, Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, Delft University of Technology, The Netherlands]{{dead link |date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110304212021/http://eprints.rclis.org/handle/10760/11158 Free book on Knowledge Technologies by Nick Milton. Check Chapter 3 on KBE by Gianfranco La Rocca (TU Delft)]
{{Common Lisp}}
[[Category:Computer-aided design software]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence]] [[Category:Common Lisp software]]

{{Discrimination sidebar}} '''Indian rolling''' (or '''Injun rollin'''')<ref name="salon">Nieves, Evelyn. ''[http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2006/09/02/navajo In Navajo country, racism rides again.]'' salon.com 2 September 2006.</ref><ref name="lisa_d">Donaldson, Lisa Weber. ''"Indian rolling": White violence against Native Americans in Farmington, New Mexico.'' Dissertation (Publication 3220935). University of New Mexico, 2006.</ref> is the assault, and in some cases murder, of [[Navajo people|Navajo]] and [[Apache people|Apache]], often of homeless individuals,<ref>Linthicum, Leslie. [http://www.abqjournal.com/upfront/19225059upfront07-19-09.htm ''Dirty Secrets Emerge After 'Indian Rolling'.''] Albuquerque Journal. 19 July 2009. Accessed 2011-03-26.</ref> committed by non-Indians in the [[Southwestern United States]], particularly in the border towns surrounding the [[Navajo Nation]] and [[Jicarilla Apache|Jicarilla lands]]. In her 2006 dissertation, Lisa Donaldson classifies ''Indian rolling'' as a "thrill-seeking hate crime" and traces its roots to the colonization of the Southwest which created a "power differential between groups that led to negative feelings toward minorities among law enforcement and local citizens".<ref name="lisa_d"/>
The assaults, which often target alcoholic men who are comparatively defenseless, are variously described as representing "rites of passage",<ref name="salon"/> "sport,"<ref name="abjournal">Linthicum, Leslie. ''[http://www.abqjournal.com/paperboy/text/news/state/168931nm05-01-04.htm Farmington Struggles With Civil Rights Issues.]'' Albuquerque Journal. 1 May 2004. Accessed 2011-03-26.</ref> and a "recreational pastime"<ref name="lisa_d"/> to the perpetrators. Survivors report the act involves being assaulted with rocks, [[pellet gun]]s, bottles, eggs, and baseball bats. Victims claim, furthermore, that law enforcement officials often refuse to intervene.<ref name="homeless">Banish, Laura. ''Homeless: ‘Indian rolling’ still takes place today.'' The Daily Times. Farmington. 23 April 2004.</ref>
The term first came to public notoriety in the spring of 1974 when three Navajos were beaten and murdered<ref name="abjournal"/> by white teenagers in the city of [[Farmington, New Mexico]], and their mutilated bodies were subsequently found in a nearby canyon.<ref name="salon"/> The perpetrators were not convicted of murder but were sent to a [[reform school]]. Subsequent protests by tribal members turned into riots when permits to march peacefully were revoked or not granted.<ref name="pluralism">[http://pluralism.org/reports/view/68 Research Report: Navajo Community and Farmington, New Mexico (2006).] The Pluralism Project at Harvard University. Accessed 2011-03-26.</ref> The incident triggered a report by the New Mexico Advisory Committee to the [[United States Commission on Civil Rights]] and inspired the [[true crime]]-novel ''The Broken Circle—A True Story of Murder and Magic in Indian Country'' by Rodney Barker.<ref name="homeless"/><ref name="circle">Barker, Rodney. ''The Broken Circle—A True Story of Murder and Magic in Indian Country.'' Simon & Schuster. New York: 1992.</ref>
Concerns about the practice's revival emerged in the 1970s to 2000s after a resurgence of attacks against Native Americans in the area.<ref name="salon"/><ref name="den_post">Draper, Electa. ''Attacks recall racist history of N.M. town.'' Denver Post. 13 July 2006.</ref> Assaults have allegedly taken place in [[Flagstaff, Arizona|Flagstaff]], [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Page, Arizona|Page]] and [[Gallup, New Mexico|Gallup]].<ref name="dirty">Linthicum, Leslie. [http://www.abqjournal.com/upfront/19225059upfront07-19-09.htm ''Dirty Secrets Emerge After 'Indian Rolling'.''] Albuquerque Journal. 19 July 2009. Accessed 2011-03-26.</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Hate crime]] *[[Lynching]] *[[Saskatoon freezing deaths]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.eric.ed.gov/PDFS/ED132236.pdf The Farmington Report: A Conflict of Cultures.] New Mexico Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights. 1975. *[http://www.createspace.com/3343379 The Farmington Report: Civil Rights for Native Americans 30 Years Later.] New Mexico Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights. 2005.
[[Category:American phraseology]] [[Category:Euphemisms]] [[Category:Hate crime]] [[Category:Anti-indigenous racism in the United States]] [[Category:Navajo history]] [[Category:Native American topics]] [[Category:Violence against indigenous peoples]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox nobility | name = John Hunyadi | image =The younger John Hunyadis grave.jpg | caption =Tomb of John Hunyadi, Jr. at [[St. Michael's Cathedral, Alba Iulia|St. Michael's Cathedral]] | title = | full name = | other titles = | succession =[[Ban of Severin]] | reign =1439–1440 | coronation = | predecessor =Franko Talovac | successor =[[John Hunyadi]] | regent = | noble family = [[House of Hunyadi]] | father = [[Voyk]] | mother = Elizabeth Morzsinai | occupation = soldier | spouse = | birth_date = ''c.'' 1419 | birth_place = | death_date = 1440 or 1441 | death_place = | issue = }} {{eastern name order|ifj. Hunyadi János}} '''John Hunyadi, Jr.''' (''c.'' 1419 – 1440 or 1441) was a [[Hungarian noble]] and [[knight banneret]] from the [[House of Hunyadi]], younger brother of regent [[John Hunyadi]] as the second son of Vajk (Voyk) and Erzsébet (Elizabeth) Morzsinai (Morsina/Marsina). There is little information about him. He was first mentioned in the charter issued for four members of his family on 12 February 1419.Kubinyi 2008, p. 8. He was appointed [[Ban of Severin]] (Szörény) by [[Albert II of Germany|King Albert]] in 1439, along with his brother.Engel 1996, p. 33. Thereafter he participated in his brother's early campaigns against the Ottomans. He was probably killed in a battle in this capacity in 1440 or 1441. He was buried in Gyulafehérvár (today: [[Alba Iulia]], [[Romania]]). His brother wrote of him as "the valiant of the valiant", showing that John the younger was regarded a brave soldier.Kubinyi 2008, p. 11. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * {{hu icon}} Engel, Pál (1996). ''Magyarország világi archontológiája, 1301–1457, I.'' ("Secular Archontology of Hungary, 1301–1457, Volume I"). História, MTA Történettudományi Intézete. Budapest. {{ISBN|963-8312-44-0}}. * Kubinyi, András (2008). ''Matthias Rex''. Balassi Kiadó. {{ISBN|978-963-506-767-1}}. ==External links== * [http://www.hunyaditura.eu/?p=hunyadiak&id=7 Hunyadi-emléktúra]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{hu icon}} {{S-start}} {{S-hou|[[House of Hunyadi]]|''c.'' 1419 ||''c.'' 1441 }} {{S-off}} {{Succession box|title=[[Ban of Severin]]
alongside [[John Hunyadi]]|before=Franko Talovac|after=[[John Hunyadi]]|years=1439–1440}} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hunyadi, John}} [[Category:1419 births]] [[Category:1440s deaths]] [[Category:Medieval Hungarian soldiers]] [[Category:Hunyadi family|John, Jr.]] [[Category:Burials at St. Michael's Cathedral, Alba Iulia]] [[Category:Knights banneret]] [[Category:15th-century Hungarian nobility]] [[Category:Bans (title)]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]]

page.title: Love Among the Ruins. A Romance of the Near Future

revision.comment: added [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the United Kingdom]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Love Among the Ruins: A Romance of the Near Future | title_orig = | translator = | image = Image:Love Among the Ruins. A Romance of the Near Future (Novel), 1st edition cover.jpg | caption = First UK edition | author = [[Evelyn Waugh]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = | publisher = [[Chapman & Hall]] | release_date = 1953 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = | isbn = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Love Among the Ruins: A Romance of the Near Future''''' is a 1953 novel by [[Evelyn Waugh]].<ref>{{Cite book | title=Google books entry | last= | first= | work=books.google.com | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=odgOl06HasQC&pg=PR36 | date= | accessdate=2008-03-05 }}</ref> It is a satire set in a dystopian quasi-egalitarian Britain.
==Plot== The protagonist, Miles Plastic, is an orphan who at the beginning of the story is finishing a prison term for [[arson]]. Crime is treated very leniently by the state, and conditions in prison are actually quite superior to those among the population at large, leading to an understandably high [[recidivism]] rate. Upon release, Plastic goes to work at a state-run [[euthanasia]] centre. The centres are not restricted to the terminally ill and are so popular that Plastic's sole responsibility is to stem "the too eager rush" of perfectly healthy but "welfare weary" citizens.
Plastic soon falls in love with Clara, a [[bearded woman]] who is a "priority case" at the centre. However, she does not wish to die (she was sent there by her department) and the two begin a romance. One day, however, she suddenly disappears, and when he finds her, she has a rubber jaw replacing her formerly bearded face. Distraught, Plastic sets his former prison on fire, and, unidentified as the perpetrator of the crime, becomes elevated in status as the prison's only "successfully rehabilitated inmate." Sent to become a lecturer on the worthiness of the prison system, Plastic is directed to marry an unattractive civil servant. A curtain is drawn on the final conclusion as Plastic reaches into his pocket for his cigarette lighter.
==References== <references />
{{Evelyn Waugh}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Love Among The Ruins: A Romance Of The Near Future}} [[Category:Novels by Evelyn Waugh]] [[Category:Dystopian novels]] [[Category:1953 British novels]] [[Category:Novels about orphans]] [[Category:Chapman & Hall books]] [[Category:Novels set in the future]] [[Category:Bearded women]] [[Category:Euthanasia]] [[Category:Arson]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the United Kingdom]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = MC 900 Ft. Jesus | image = | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Mark Griffin | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1957}} | birth_place = [[Kentucky]], U.S. | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]], [[jazz]], [[Experimental music|experimental]] | occupation = Musician | years_active = 1979–2001, 2017-present | label = [[I.R.S. Records]]
[[American Recordings (US)|American Recordings]]
[[Nettwerk]] | associated_acts = [[The Telefones]]
Lithium X-Mas
[[Bill Evans (saxophonist)|Bill Evans]] | website = }} '''Mark Griffin''' (born 1957), better known as '''MC 900 Ft. Jesus''', is an American [[classical music|classically]] trained musician{{cite news|last=Chamy|first=Michael|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2001-10-18/music/spider-webs/|title=Spider Webs: Mark Griffin resurrects MC 900 Ft. Jesus|date=October 18, 2001|newspaper=[[Dallas Observer]]|publisher=[[Voice Media Group]]|location=Dallas, Texas|accessdate=2014-11-13}} turned [[rapping|rapper]] and experimental musician.{{cite web|last=Brennan|first=Carol|url=http://www.musicianguide.com/biographies/1608001055/MC-900-Ft-Jesus.html|title=MC 900 Ft. Jesus Biography|website=Musicianguide.com|accessdate=2014-11-13}} MC 900 Ft. Jesus' music is influenced by [[hip hop music|hip hop]], incorporating many [[sampling (music)|sound samples]]. ==Early life and education== The son of an army officer, Griffin moved around quite a bit before settling in [[Dallas (Texas)|Dallas]], [[Texas]] in 1979.{{cite news|last=Heim|first=Chris|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-04-13/entertainment/9001310286_1_ft-jesus-rap-musical-mix|title=An Encounter With Mc 900 Ft Jesus|date=April 13, 1990|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=2014-11-13}} Griffin studied the trumpet and has a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[Music#Academia|Music]] from [[Morehead State University]] as well as an [[Postgraduate education|advanced degree]] in music from [[North Texas State University]]. Before becoming MC 900 Ft. Jesus, Griffin played in local Dallas bands [[The Telefones]] and Lithium X-Mas. ==Career== ''[[Hell with the Lid Off]]'' (1990) was Griffin's first full-length release for MC 900 Ft. Jesus as well as the first time Griffin had appeared on a major record label. Featuring DJ Zero (Patrick Rollins) and the single "Truth is Out of Style" which gained a cult following.{{cite news|last=Migaldi|first=Renaldo|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/mc-900-ft-jesus-with-dj-zero/Content?oid=875487|title=MC 900 Ft. Jesus with DJ Zero|date=April 12, 1990|newspaper=[[Chicago Reader]]|publisher=[[Sun-Times Media Group]]|accessdate=2014-11-13}} The following year ''Welcome to My Dream'' (1991) was released. DJ Zero appears on ''Welcome to My Dream'' under his real name, Patrick Rollins, because of uncertainty about whether he would have been able to tour in support of the album.{{cite news|last=Popson|first=Tom|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1991-11-08/entertainment/9104100619_1_ft-jesus-cameras-magazine|title=Mc 900 Ft Jesus: A Fascination With Aberration|date=November 8, 1991|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=2014-11-13}} His subsequent single, "The City Sleeps", was featured in the album in which explored the mind of a serial [[arsonist]]. The song sparked controversy in [[Baltimore]] when a then [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] affiliate, [[WJZ-TV|WJZ]], ran a report suggesting that a series of arson in the area was a result of [[WHFS (historic)|WHFS]] allowing the song play time.https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1992/01/29/on-the-beat/5911bb51-a181-4dba-8675-1eaeab741822/ His final album, ''[[One Step Ahead of the Spider]]'', was released in 1994; it contained the single "If I Only Had a Brain", which became his best-known song. The song gained increased exposure from the music video directed for it by [[Spike Jonze]],{{cite news|last=Vognar|first=Chris|url=http://popcultureblog.dallasnews.com/2014/01/spike-jonze-dishes-on-his-classic-music-videos-and-dallas-mc-900-ft-jesus.html/|title=Spike Jonze dishes on his classic music videos (and Dallas'MC 900 Ft. Jesus)|date=January 7, 2014|newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|accessdate=2014-11-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113084852/http://popcultureblog.dallasnews.com/2014/01/spike-jonze-dishes-on-his-classic-music-videos-and-dallas-mc-900-ft-jesus.html/|archivedate=November 13, 2014|df=mdy-all}} as well as exposure on MTV's ''[[Beavis and Butt-Head]]'' cartoon show.{{cite news|last=Hughey|first= Jesse|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2008-01-31/music/900-ft-jesus-lives/|title=MC 900 Ft. Jesus Lives|newspaper=[[Dallas Observer]]|publisher=[[Voice Media Group]]|location=Dallas, Texas|accessdate=2014-11-13}} Rollins once again appears but is not listed in the credits. ===Retirement from music industry=== Griffin eventually became disillusioned with the music industry, and following unproductive sessions for his fourth album, felt he had taken his style of music as far as he wanted to go and overall losing interest in music citing [[alcoholism]].http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/mc-900-ft-jesus-on-walking-away-from-his-career-i-lost-my-sense-of-humor-about-it-9092749 Record label interest waned and eventually in 2001, Griffin officially retired. Needing a new direction, he gained his commercial pilot's license, hoping to become a flight instructor. However, when the [[September 11 attacks]] occurred, demand plummeted for flight instructors and Griffin was unable to find a job. Eventually, Griffin took a job at a [[Borders Group|Borders]] bookstore.http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/mc-900-ft-jesus-lives-6419623 In 2007, he began DJing weekly at a Dallas music venue, Lee Harvey's, located in the [[Cedars, Dallas|Cedars]] neighborhood next to downtown. ===Coming out of retirement=== On November 26, 2016, Griffin announced via Facebook that he was set to perform a show at The Kessler Theater in [[Dallas]] with a quartet including Chris McGuire, Greg Beck, and Wanz Dover in hopes of kick-starting a tour as well as a possible fourth album with his former label [[Nettwerk]] of which had approached Griffin about. On February 3, 2017, the quartet played a sold-out concert performing several of the MC 900 songs, receiving a rapturous ovation.http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/mc-900-ft-jesus-returns-with-a-sold-out-show-at-the-kessler-9161473 ===Name=== Griffin's stage name came from a sermon by [[Oral Roberts]], in which the [[televangelist]] claimed that he had received a vision of a {{convert|900|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} Jesus, who commanded him to build [[CityPlex Towers|a hospital]] on the campus of [[Oral Roberts University]]. == Discography == === Albums === *''[[Hell with the Lid Off]]'' (1989): MC 900 Ft. Jesus With DJ Zero *''[[Welcome to My Dream (album)|Welcome to My Dream]]'' (1991): MC 900 Ft. Jesus *''[[One Step Ahead of the Spider]]'': (1994) MC 900 Ft. Jesus === Singles === *''Too Bad / Shut Up'': (1988) MC 900 Ft. Jesus With DJ Zero *''I'm Going Straight To Heaven'': (1989) MC 900 Ft. Jesus With DJ Zero *''Truth Is Out of Style'': (1989) MC 900 Ft. Jesus With DJ Zero *''UFO's Are Real'': (1990) MC 900 Ft. Jesus With DJ Zero *''Killer Inside Me'': (1991) MC 900 Ft. Jesus *''The City Sleeps'': (1991) MC 900 Ft. Jesus *''If I Only Had A Brain'': (1994) MC 900 Ft. Jesus *''But If You Go'': (1994) MC 900 Ft. Jesus *''Falling Elevators'': (1996) MC 900 Ft. Jesus == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.earpollution.com/vol3/oct01/profiles/mc900ftjesus/mc900ftjesus.html Oct 2001 Interview by Jeff Ashley] *[https://www.facebook.com/Mc900FtJesus/ The Official MC 900ft Jesus Facebook Page] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:900 Ft. Jesus, MC}} [[Category:American male rappers]] [[Category:American hip hop DJs|Nine Hundred Foot Jesus]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rappers from Dallas]] [[Category:1957 births]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by 2601:644:4200:4AB7:A065:31C2:4F71:88CB: Please provide a source for this claim. I have this article from the New York Times that says he was calf-roping. https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/obituaries/commerce-secretary-baldrige-dies-in-rodeo-accident-in-california.html. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{for|his father, the Congressman from Nebraska|Howard M. Baldrige}} {{redirect|Malcolm Baldridge|the oceanographic research ship|NOAAS Researcher (R 103)}} {{Infobox Officeholder | image = Malcolm Baldridge pers0138.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | order = 26th | office = United States Secretary of Commerce | term_start = January 20, 1981 | term_end = July 25, 1987 | deputy = | president = [[Ronald Reagan]] | predecessor = [[Philip M. Klutznick]] | successor = [[William Verity Jr.|C. William Verity]] | birth_name = Howard Malcolm Baldrige Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date|1922|10|04}} | birth_place = [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha]], [[Nebraska]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1987|07|25|1922|10|04}} | death_place = [[Walnut Creek, California|Walnut Creek]], [[California]], U.S. | resting_place = North Cemetery in [[Woodbury, Connecticut|Woodbury]], [[Connecticut]], U.S. | nationality = [[United States|American]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = Margaret Trowbridge Murray Baldrige
(m. 1951 - 1987; until his death) | relations = Robert Connell Baldridge
[[Letitia Baldrige]] | children = Megan Brewster Baldrige
Mary Trowbridge Baldrige | parents = [[Howard M. Baldrige|Howard Malcolm Baldrige, Sr.]]
Regina Katherine Connell Baldrige | residence = | alma_mater = [[Yale University]] | occupation = [[Foundryman]], [[Rodeo]] team roper, [[Businessman]] | profession = [[Businessman]] | religion = [[Congregationalist]] | signature = }} '''Howard Malcolm "Mac" Baldrige Jr.''' (October 4, 1922{{spaced ndash}}July 25, 1987) was an American businessman. He served as the [[United States Secretary of Commerce]] from 1981 until his death in 1987. He was inducted into the [[ProRodeo Hall of Fame]] in 1988. ==Biography== ===Early life and career=== Baldrige was born on October 4, 1922 in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. He was the son of [[Howard M. Baldrige|H. Malcolm Baldrige, Sr.]] (1894–1985), a [[United States House of Representatives|congressman]] from [[Nebraska]], and the former Regina Katherine Connell (1896–1967). He had a brother, Robert Connell Baldridge (he alone returned the second "d" to his last name, which had been dropped in previous generations), and a sister, [[Letitia Baldrige]]. He attended [[The Hotchkiss School]] and [[Yale University]]. At Yale, he was a member of a [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]]. Baldrige began his career in the manufacturing industry in 1947, as the foundry hand in an iron company in [[Connecticut]] and rose to the presidency of that company by 1960. During [[World War II]], Baldrige served in combat in the Pacific as Captain in the 27th Infantry Division. On March 31, 1951, Baldrige married Margaret "Midge" Trowbridge Murray, with whom he had two daughters. Prior to entering the Cabinet, Baldrige was chairman and chief executive officer of [[Waterbury, Connecticut]]-based brass company Scovill, Inc. Having joined Scovill in 1962, he is credited with leading its transformation to a highly diversified manufacturer of consumer, housing and industrial goods from a financially troubled [[brass mill]]. ===Secretary of Commerce=== [[File:HowardMalcolmBaldridgeMicrophone.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Malcolm Baldrige Jr.]] Baldrige was nominated to be Secretary of Commerce by President-elect [[Ronald Reagan]] on December 11, 1980, and confirmed by the [[United States Senate]] on January 22, 1981. During his tenure, Baldrige played a major role in developing and carrying out Administration trade policy. He took the lead in resolving difficulties in technology transfers with [[China]] and [[India]]. Baldrige held the first [[United States Cabinet|Cabinet]]-level talks with the [[Soviet Union]] in seven years which paved the way for increased access for U.S. firms to the Soviet market. He was highly regarded by the world's most preeminent leaders. [[File:HowardMalcolmBaldridgeWithImeldaMarcos.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Baldrige with [[Imelda Marcos]]]] Leading the Administration's ward effort to pass the Export Trading Company Act of 1982, Baldrige was named by the President to chair a Cabinet-level Trade Strike Force to search out unfair trading practices and recommend ways to end those practices. He was the leader in the reform of the nation's [[antitrust]] laws. Baldrige's award-winning managerial excellence contributed to long-term improvement in economy, efficiency, and effectiveness in government. Within the Commerce Department, Baldrige reduced the budget by more than 30% and administrative personnel by 25%. "How Plain English Works for Business, Twelve Case Studies" was published by the U.S. Department of Commerce with his introduction, in 1984. In it were twelve chapters on how "translations" of complex legal wording or bureaucratic jargon could be simplified and made more clear to any reader. In the section on insurance policy language, an example showed the cumbersome nature of "While this policy has a loan value, the owner may obtain an advance from XYZ Company upon assignment of the policy as sole security." It became "You can get a loan from us on your policy while it has a loan value. The policy can be the sole security for the loan." Baldrige's introduction read, in part, "Talking or writing in plain English is a challenge to both the private and public sectors. In this book of case studies, 12 corporations and trade associations tell how they met this challenge. I am grateful for the efforts their officials have given to this partnership project." [[File:HowardMalcolmBaldridge.jpg|thumb|right|Malcolm Baldrige Jr.]] Baldrige worked during his boyhood as a ranch hand and earned several awards as a professional team roper on the [[rodeo]] circuit. He was the [[Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association]]'s Rodeo Man of the Year in 1981 and was installed in the Hall of Great Westerners of the [[National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum|National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum]] in [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], in 1984.{{cite web|title=Hall of Great Westerners|url=https://nationalcowboymuseum.org/hall-of-great-westerners/|website=National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum|accessdate=3 June 2017}} Baldrige once appeared on the television game show ''[[To Tell the Truth]]'' pretending to be rodeo tie-down roping champion Dean Oliver. He was inducted into the [[ProRodeo Hall of Fame]] in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]], in 1988, rodeo's highest honor.{{cite web|title=Malcolm "Mac" Baldrige - Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame|url=http://www.prorodeohalloffame.com/inductees/by-category/notableslifetime-achievement/malcolm-mac-baldrige/|website=Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame|accessdate=3 June 2017}} ===Death and legacy=== Secretary of Commerce Baldrige died in [[Northern California]] on July 25, 1987, after sustaining internal injuries from a [[rodeo]] accident while participating in a calf-roping competition when the horse he was riding fell on him at the Jack Roddy Ranch in [[Brentwood, California|Brentwood]] in east [[Contra Costa County, California|Contra Costa County]], {{convert|45|mi|-1}} east of [[San Francisco]]. Following the accident, Baldrige was flown by helicopter to [[John Muir Health#John Muir Medical Center.2C Walnut Creek|John Muir Hospital]] in [[Walnut Creek, California]], but his internal injuries were too severe.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/26/obituaries/commerce-secretary-baldrige-dies-in-rodeo-accident-in-california.html|newspaper=New York Times|agency=Associated Press|title=Commerce Secretary Baldrige dies in rodeo accident in California|date=July 26, 1987|accessdate=April 27, 2013}} Baldrige was buried in North Cemetery in [[Woodbury, Connecticut]]. His service as Secretary of Commerce was one of the longest in history. Baldrige is said to have been possibly the most colorful Secretary of Commerce and one of the most beloved. {{cite web|title=Malcolm Baldrige Biography|url=http://www.baldrige.nist.gov/Biography.htm|website=www.baldrige.nist.gov|publisher=NIST|accessdate=31 May 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527223433/http://www.baldrige.nist.gov/Biography.htm|archivedate=May 27, 2010|language=en|date=December 18, 2015}} Baldrige was a proponent of quality management as a key to his country's prosperity and long-term strength. He took a personal interest in the legislation that became the [https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/100/hr812 Quality Improvement Act of 1987] and helped draft one of the early versions. In recognition of his contributions, Congress named the annual award (see [[Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award]]) for product quality in his honor.{{cite web|url=https://www.nist.gov/public_affairs/factsheet/baldfaqs.htm|title=Frequently Asked Questions and Answers about the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award (November 2006)|website=www.nist.gov|dead-url=|accessdate=May 31, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115163607/https://www.nist.gov/public_affairs/factsheet/baldfaqs.htm|archivedate=November 15, 2006}} In 1987, after his death, the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] renamed the [[Oceanography|oceanographic]] [[research ship]] [[NOAAS Researcher (R 103)|NOAAS ''Researcher'' (R 103)]] in Baldrige{{'}}s honor, the ship becoming NOAAS ''Malcolm Baldrige'' (R 103).{{cite web|title=NOAA History - Tools of the Trade/Ships/C&GS Ships/RESEARCHER|url=http://www.history.noaa.gov/ships/researcher.html|website=www.history.noaa.gov|accessdate=May 31, 2017}} On October 17, 1988, Baldrige was presented posthumously with the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] by the President [[Ronald Reagan]]. ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} *How Plain English Works for Business, Twelve Case Studies, U.S. Department of Commerce, Office of Consumer Affairs, March, 1984. 102 pages; 003-000-00631-0; U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|6807529|Howard Malcolm Baldrige Jr.}} *[http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1988/101788b.htm ''Remarks at the Presentation Ceremony for the Presidential Medal of Freedom - October 17, 1988''] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{U.S. Cabinet official box |before = [[Philip M. Klutznick]] |after = [[William Verity Jr.|C. William Verity]] |years = January 20, 1981 – July 25, 1987 |president = [[Ronald Reagan]] |department = Secretary of Commerce}} {{s-end}} {{USSecCommerce}} {{Reagan cabinet}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baldrige, Malcolm Jr.}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:American chief executives of manufacturing companies]] [[Category:United States Secretaries of Commerce]] [[Category:Reagan administration cabinet members]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients]] [[Category:American Congregationalists]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:Foundrymen]] [[Category:Hotchkiss School alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Sports deaths in California]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Politicians from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:ProRodeo Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Roping (rodeo)]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Mary Kills People | image = | caption = | genre = {{Plainlist| *[[Drama]] *[[Black comedy]] }} | creator = Tara Armstrong | based_on = | developer = | writer = | director = Holly Dale | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = [[Caroline Dhavernas]] | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = Canada | language = English | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 12 | list_episodes = #Episodes | executive_producer = [[Tassie Cameron]] | producer = | cinematography = | editor = | camera = | runtime = 42–44 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * [[Entertainment One]] * [[Corus Entertainment]] * Cameron Pictures Inc. }} | distributor = Entertainment One | network = [[Global Television Network|Global]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|2017|1|25}} | last_aired = present | related = | website = http://www.globaltv.com/marykillspeople/ | production_website = | image_alt = }} '''''Mary Kills People''''' is a Canadian [[dramedy|drama]]{{cite news|last1=Doyle|first1=John|title=Mary Kills People is a killer of a good, provocative drama|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/television/doyle-mary-kills-people-is-a-killer-of-a-good-provocative-drama/article33717877/|work=The Globe and Mail|date=January 24, 2017|accessdate=February 24, 2017}} television series starring [[Caroline Dhavernas]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.corusent.com/news/global-ignites-schedule-massive-star-power-11-new-series-join-20162017-primetime-lineup/|title=Global Ignites Its Schedule With Massive Star Power As 11 New Series Join Its 2016/2017 Primetime Lineup|publisher=Corus Entertainment}} It premiered on [[Global Television Network|Global]] on January 25, 2017. On June 5, 2017, the series was renewed for a second season,{{cite web|url=http://www.tv-eh.com/2017/06/05/corus-entertainment-bolsters-its-201718-programming-slate-with-new-and-returning-canadian-original-productions/|title=Corus Entertainment bolsters its 2017/18 programming slate with new and returning Canadian original productions|date=June 5, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017|publisher=TV, eh}} which was scheduled to premiere on Global's [[video-on-demand]] platforms on January 1 before premiering on television on January 3, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.corusent.com/news/season-2-globals-critically-acclaimed-original-series-mary-kills-people-returns-january-3/|title=SEASON 2 OF GLOBAL’S CRITICALLY ACCLAIMED ORIGINAL SERIES MARY KILLS PEOPLE RETURNS JANUARY 3|work=[[Corus Entertainment]]|date=November 30, 2017|accessdate=November 30, 2017}} ==Premise== Dr. Mary Harris works at the emergency department of the Eden General Hospital and has a side business as an end of life counselor—she and her partner Des provide [[assisted suicide]]. Their lives get complicated when the police start investigating them. ==Cast== * [[Caroline Dhavernas]] as Dr. Mary Harris * [[Jay Ryan (actor)|Jay Ryan]] as Detective Ben Wesley, who is investigating Mary and goes undercover briefly as terminally ill patient Joel Collins * [[Richard Short (actor)|Richard Short]] as Desmond "Des" Bennett, Mary's business partner * [[Lyriq Bent]] as Detective Frank Gaines, who is working the case with Ben * [[Greg Bryk]] as Grady Burgess, Des's former drug dealer who provided him and Mary with [[pentobarbital]] (season 1) * [[Sebastien Roberts]] as Kevin, Mary's ex-husband * Abigail Winter as Jessica "Jess", Mary's teenage daughter * [[Charlotte Sullivan]] as Nicole Mitchell, Mary's sister * [[Grace Lynn Kung]] as Annie Chung, a nurse at Eden General who refers patients to Mary and Des * Jess Salgueiro as Larissa, Des's girlfriend *Katie Douglas as Naomi, Jess's friend *[[Alexandra Castillo]] as Louise Malick, a lawyer who is Naomi's mother and Kevin's girlfriend *[[Joel Thomas Hynes]] as Sidney "Sid" Thomas-Haye (season 1) *Lola Flanery as Cambie, Mary's younger daughter *[[Terra Hazelton]] as Rhonda McCartney, a nurse at Eden General *[[Matt Gordon]] as Dr. Dennis Taylor *[[Rachelle Lefevre]] as Olivia Bloom, Grady's sister (season 2) == Production == The series, which was to comprise six episodes, was commissioned by TV network [[Global Television Network|Global]] on January 28, 2016.{{cite press release | url=http://media.shawmedia.ca/uploadedfiles/shawmedia/content/pressreleases/2016/january/mary%20kills%20people%20green%20light%20announcement_final.pdf | title=Global Green Lights Gripping New Canadian Original Drama Mary Kills People | publisher=Shaw Media | accessdate=January 29, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://etcanada.com/news/37711/mary-kills-people-provocative-medical-drama-gets-greenlit/|title=‘Mary Kills People’: Provocative Medical Drama Gets Greenlit|first=Brent|last=Furdyk|work=ET Canada|date=January 28, 2016|publisher=}} Production began in summer 2016,{{cite press release|url=http://www.corusent.com/properties/global-mary-kills-people/|title=Global - Mary Kills People|publisher=Corus Entertainment}} and the first episode aired January 25, 2017. In the United States, the series was picked up by [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] on October 13, 2016. The channel came on board as a co-producer and was involved in creative aspects of the project, including casting. ''Mary Kills People'' premiered in the US on Lifetime on April 23, 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.metronews.ca/entertainment/2017/01/23/why-mary-is-ready-to-thrill-people.html|title=Mary's an elegant mercy killer, ready to thrill people|date=January 23, 2017|accessdate=April 17, 2017|first=Chris|last=Alexander|work=[[Metro International]]}} As of January 23, 2017, there were talks to produce a second season according to [[Metro News]] and Caroline Dhavernas. On June 5, 2017, the series was renewed for a six-episode followup season. Production occurred over summer 2017 in Toronto. Lifetime announced their pickup of the second season in the United States on July 28, 2017;{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/unreal-renewed-season-4-lifetime-mary-kills-people-renewed-season-2-1202509680/|title=‘UnREAL’ Renewed for Season 4 at Lifetime, ‘Mary Kills People’ Renewed for Season 2|first=Joe|last=Otterson|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 28, 2017|accessdate=November 30, 2017}} it premiered on March 12, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/lifetimetv/status/967881900730630144|title=Mary kills people, and she is BACK. Tune in to the premiere of an all-new season of #MaryKillsPeople on March 12th at 9/8c.|accessdate=February 26, 2018}} == Episodes == ===Season 1 (2017)=== {{Episode table |background=#812f09 |overall=6 |title=17 |director=11 |writer=17 |airdate=10 |viewers=9 |prodcode=7 |country= Canada |viewers |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = Bloody Mary | DirectedBy = Holly Dale | WrittenBy = Tara Armstrong | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|1|25}} | ProdCode = 1–01 | Viewers = 1.059{{cite web|url=http://assets.numeris.ca/Downloads/January%2023,%202017%20-%20January%2029,%202017%20(National).pdf|title=Top Programs – Total Canada (English) January 23, 2017 - January 29, 2017|work=[[Numeris]]}} | ShortSummary = After the pentobarbital proves inefficient with a patient, Mary finds out the entire batch had been diluted. Mary and Des meet with a new patient, Joel, for the first time. Mary makes a romantic advance on Joel but leaves when he asks her to give him the pento on the spot. Joel is revealed to be a cop. | LineColor = 812f09}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = The River Styx | DirectedBy = Holly Dale | WrittenBy = Mike Goldbach | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|2|1}} | ProdCode = 1–02 | Viewers = 1.045{{cite web|url=http://assets.numeris.ca/Downloads/January%2030,%202017%20-%20February%205,%202017%20(National).pdf|title=Top Programs – Total Canada (English) January 30, 2017 - February 5, 2017|work=[[Numeris]]}} | ShortSummary = Mary suggests other options to Joel, who firmly refuses before giving her a call to let her know he would take matters into his own hands. She decides to help him, but after she is unable to find the medication, she realizes he is a cop. Mary gets rid of the pento before she gets a call from Des telling her that they need to help a patient immediately, which forces her to go to Grady herself to get more. Joel reveals his real name, Ben, to Mary while she maintains her innocence. | LineColor = 812f09}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = Wave the White Flag | DirectedBy = Holly Dale | WrittenBy = Marsha Greene | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|2|8}} | ProdCode = 1–03 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Sid shows up at the Eden General emergency department with a leg injury and under police custody. Grady uses Mary's daughter Jess to get her to break Sid out; Grady then kills Sid, so he does not make a deal with the police. Ben and Frank look into Troy Dixon's death. | LineColor = 812f09}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | Title = Raised By Wolves | DirectedBy = Holly Dale | WrittenBy = Tara Armstrong | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|2|15}} | ProdCode = 1–04 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Grady tells Mary he knows about her side business with Des and wants in on it. Ben follows Mary to her childhood home and meets her sister, Nicole. He then finds out their real last name is Mitchell, and Mary changed it to Harris after her mother's death—which she was investigated for. Frank persuades Des to help the police gather evidence against Mary in exchange for immunity. | LineColor = 812f09}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | Title = The Judas Cradle | DirectedBy = Holly Dale | WrittenBy = Sherry White | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|2|22}} | ProdCode = 1–05 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Ben goes to Des's place with the wire and finds out he is high. They decide to continue with the plan, but Des shows Mary the wire before anything incriminating is recorded. She later meets the patient alone and, after giving him the drink, tells him about her mother. Des overdoses but Mary is able to save him, ending their partnership afterwards. She takes the files he had in his house and buries them, then offers Grady the chance to be her new partner. | LineColor = 812f09}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = Morning Glory | DirectedBy = Holly Dale | WrittenBy = Tara Armstrong & Tassie Cameron & Marsha Greene | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2017|2|22}} | ProdCode = 1–06 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = After Grady agrees to be Mary's new partner, she shows him the files of three clients—Morgan Lewis, Ethan Grant and Troy Dixon—before trying to teach him how to do the injections; he insists he can do it with her assistance. She agrees, and he injects her with watered down pento thinking it was saline. Des calls Frank telling him he wants to make a statement, which Frank presumes will implicate Mary, but when Des arrives at the station he claims Mary is innocent and instead places the blame on Grady. Mary calls Ben and tells him that Grady drugged her and is going to kill her. Ben arrives at Grady's house and fatally shoots him. Nicole tells Mary she wants to be part of her business. | LineColor = 812f09}} }} ===Season 2 (2018)=== {{Episode table |background=#F77F00 |overall=6 |title=17 |director=11 |writer=17 |airdate=10 |viewers=9 |prodcode=7 |country= Canada |viewers |episodes= {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 1 | Title = The Means | DirectedBy = Kelly Makin | WrittenBy = Tara Armstrong | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|1|03}} | ProdCode = 2–01 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Des is happy to reteam with Mary following his stint in prison. But a routine case with a devastating outcome has her rethinking their partnership. | LineColor = F77F00}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 2 | Title = The Connection | DirectedBy = Kelly Makin | WrittenBy = Lara Azzopardi | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|1|10}} | ProdCode = 2–02 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = When Olivia attempts to blackmail Mary, she is drawn deeper into a deadly game of cat and mouse that has a surprising connection to Ben. | LineColor = F77F00}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 3 | Title = Twin Flames | DirectedBy = Norma Bailey | WrittenBy = Marsha Greene | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|1|17}} | ProdCode = 2–03 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Mary and Ben decide to join forces and hide Travis at Ben's secluded trailer. But when Travis reveals a crucial detail about Ben's investigation, Mary is forced to reconsider their alliance. | LineColor = F77F00}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 4 | Title = Ride or Die | DirectedBy = Norma Bailey | WrittenBy = Morwyn Brebner | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|1|24}} | ProdCode = 2–04 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Following the disappearance of Travis, Des worries that he and Mary may have crossed a moral line from which they can never return. After jeopardizing Ben's investigation of Olivia, Mary tries to make amends, which has repercussions for a patient in dire need. | LineColor = F77F00}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 5 | Title = Come to Jesus | DirectedBy = David Wellington | WrittenBy = Lara Azzopardi & Tassie Cameron & Marsha Greene | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|1|31}} | ProdCode = 2–05 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = All seems well for Mary, Ben has forgiven her, and she and Des have decided to move forward with the death retreat. The only nagging concern for Mary: her daughter Jess hates her and doesn't believe a word out of her mouth. | LineColor = F77F00}} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = Fatal Flaw | DirectedBy = David Wellington | WrittenBy = Tara Armstrong & Morwyn Brebner | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|2|07}} | ProdCode = 2–06 | Viewers = | ShortSummary = Mary decides to wear a wire in order to help Ben take down Olivia, but when their plan takes an unexpected turn, Mary must reconsider her allegiance. As Des and Nicole prepare for Brendan's death, Des faces crippling self-doubt about his dream. | LineColor = F77F00}} }} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== The first season has received a score of 66 on [[Metacritic]], indicating generally favourable reviews, based on eight reviews,{{cite web|title=Mary Kills People (2017) Season 1|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/mary-kills-people|website=Metacritic|accessdate=23 August 2017}} and a rating of 100% on review aggregate website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on ten reviews, the site's critical consensus stating: "''Mary Kills People'' is more than its unique premise, with a layered lead performance and consistently entertaining narrative keeping the show's dark comedy grounded in relatable reality."{{cite web|title=Mary Kills People (2017) Season 1|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/mary_kills_people/s01/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=23 August 2017}} [[John Doyle (critic)|John Doyle]] of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' called the first episode of the show "remarkably assured, droll and adult. It’s very smart and utterly intriguing." He praises Mary Harris as "one of the most compelling, original female characters in years" and Caroline Dhavernas as "exceptional" in her portrayal: "Perhaps the best thing about it is the crazy sparkle in Mary’s eyes. There is something anarchic bubbling inside her."{{cite news|last1=Doyle|first1=John|title=Mary Kills People is a killer of a good, provocative drama|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/television/doyle-mary-kills-people-is-a-killer-of-a-good-provocative-drama/article33717877/|work=The Globe and Mail|date=January 24, 2017|accessdate=February 24, 2017}} [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']]'s Maureen Ryan said the show "pulls off a melding of tones — comedic, dramatic, and philosophical — that seems next to impossible," but criticized the first season's romance subplots.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/reviews/mary-kills-people-lifetime-caroline-dhavernas-1202029437/|title=TV Review: ‘Mary Kills People’ on Lifetime, Starring Caroline Dhavernas|first=Maureen|last=Ryan|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|date=April 12, 2017|accessdate=April 17, 2017}} ===Awards=== ;[[Canadian Screen Awards]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Category !! Nominee(s) !! Result !! {{abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | rowspan=9|[[6th Canadian Screen Awards|2018]] || [[Academy of Canadian Cinema and Television Award for Best Dramatic Series|Best Dramatic Series]] || Tassie Cameron, Amy Cameron, Jocelyn Hamilton, Tecca Crosby, Tara Armstrong, Holly Dale || {{nom}} || rowspan=9|{{cite web|title=2018 TV Nominees - Academy.ca|url=https://www.academy.ca/category/2018-tv-nominees/|website=Academy.ca|accessdate=February 26, 2018}} |- | Best Direction, Drama Series || Holly Dale
(episode: "The River Styx") || {{won}} |- | Best Writing, Drama Series || Tara Armstrong
(episode: "Bloody Mary") || {{nom}} |- | Best Writing, Drama Series || Marsha Greene
(episode: "Wave the White Flag") || {{nom}} |- | Best Achievement in Casting || Susan Forrest, Sharon Forrest || {{nom}} |- | [[Academy of Canadian Cinema and Television Award for Best Performance by an Actor in a Continuing Leading Dramatic Role|Best Lead Actor, Drama Series]] || Richard Short || {{nom}} |- | Best Supporting Actor, Drama Series || Greg Bryk || {{nom}} |- | [[Academy of Canadian Cinema and Television Award for Best Performance by an Actress in a Continuing Leading Dramatic Role|Best Lead Actress, Drama Series]] || Caroline Dhavernas || {{nom}} |- | Best Guest Performance, Drama Series || Steven McCarthy
(episode: "The Judas Cradle") || {{won}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|tt6236572}} {{Global Television Network Shows (current and upcoming)}} {{Lifetime Shows}} [[Category:2010s Canadian drama television series]] [[Category:Global Television Network shows]] [[Category:Television series by Entertainment One]] [[Category:Television series by Corus Entertainment]] [[Category:2017 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:Lifetime (TV network) shows]] [[Category:Euthanasia in fiction]]

{{Infobox ice hockey player | name = Mikkel Aagaard | image = {{CSS image crop|Image = Mikkel Aagaard.jpg|bSize = 380|cWidth = 200|cHeight = 310|oTop = 110|oLeft = 0|Location = center}} | image_size = 230px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1995|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Frederikshavn]], Denmark | height_cm = 184 | weight_kg = 81 | position = [[Centre (ice hockey)|Centre]] | shoots = Left | league = | team = Free agent | former_teams = [[Frederikshavn White Hawks]]
[[Stockton Heat]]
[[Springfield Thunderbirds]] | ntl_team = DNK | draft = Undrafted | career_start = 2013 | career_end = }} '''Mikkel Aagaard''' (born 18 October 1995) is a [[Danes|Danish]] professional [[ice hockey]] [[Forward (ice hockey)|forward]] who is currently an [[unrestricted free agent]]. He most recently played with the [[Manchester Monarchs (ECHL)|Manchester Monarchs]] in the [[ECHL]]. ==Playing career== Undrafted, Aagaard played in his native Denmark with [[Frederikshavn White Hawks]] before moving to North America to play major junior hockey in the [[Ontario Hockey League]] with the [[Niagara IceDogs]] and [[Sudbury Wolves]]. On October 5, 2016, he embarked on his North American pro career in signing with the [[Stockton Heat]] of the AHL for the [[2016–17 AHL season|2016–17]] season.{{cite web|url=http://www.eliteprospects.com/player.php?player=46502|title=Mikkel Aagaard player profile | website = ''EliteProspects.com'' | date = 2016-05-04 | accessdate = 2016-05-04}} Aagaard split the season between the Heat and its ECHL affiliate, the [[Adirondack Thunder]]. He compiled 11 points in 25 games with the Heat before appearing in 4 post-season games with the club. As a free agent from the Heat, Aagaard opted to continue in the AHL after securing a try-out to attend the [[Springfield Thunderbirds]] training camp. In making a positive impression, Aagaard was signed to a standard one-year deal with the Thunderbirds for the [[2017–18 AHL season|2017–18]] season on October 4, 2017.{{citeweb| url = http://www.springfieldthunderbirds.com/news/detail/thunderbirds-sign-f-aagaard | title = Thunderbirds sign Forward Aagaard | publisher = ''[[Springfield Thunderbirds]]'' | date = 2017-10-04 | accessdate = 2017-10-04}} Aagard appeared in 23 games with Springfield before he was re-assigned to ECHL affiliate, the [[Manchester Monarchs (ECHL)|Manchester Monarchs]], then later released from his contract on February 1, 2018.{{citeweb| url = https://theahl.com/stats/transactions/411/57?page=1 | title = Springfield Thunderbirds transactions | publisher = ''[[American Hockey League]]'' | date = 2018-02-01 | accessdate = 2018-02-01}} ==Career statistics== ===Regular season and playoffs=== {| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center; width:60em" |- bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! colspan="3" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! colspan="5" | [[Regular season]] ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" | ! colspan="5" | [[Playoffs]] |- bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! revision.comment: Migrate {{Infobox museum}} coordinates parameters to {{Coord}}, see [[Wikipedia:Coordinates in infoboxes]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Companies|date=August 2015}} {{refimprove|date=August 2015}} }} {{Infobox museum | name = Museum Tot Zover | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | map_type = Netherlands Amsterdam Greater | map_relief = | map_size = 250px | map_caption = Location in the city of Amsterdam | map_dot_label = | coordinates = {{coord|52|20|46|N|4|56|19|E|region:NL-NH|display=inline,title}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|2007|12|19|df=y}}Bert van Panhuis, "[http://www.trouw.nl/tr/nl/4324/Nieuws/article/detail/1330568/2007/12/19/Wegens-omstandigheden-geopend.dhtml Wegens omstandigheden geopend]", ''[[Trouw]]'', 2007. Retrieved 10 September 2015. | dissolved = | location = Kruislaan 124[http://www.totzover.nl/index.php?page=contact Contact], Museum Tot Zover. Retrieved 10 September 2015.
[[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = Guus Sluiter[http://www.totzover.nl/index.php?page=organisatie Organisatie], Museum Tot Zover. Retrieved 10 September 2015. | president = | chairperson = | curator = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|www.totzover.nl}} | embedded = }} The '''Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover''' (Dutch Funeral Museum So Far) is a [[List of museums in Amsterdam|museum]] in [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] that displays the various funerary practices of the various cultures present in the Netherlands, with the view that these funerary practices provide a better understanding of these cultures.{{cite web|title=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover|url=http://www.anwb.nl/landvananwb/nederlands-uitvaart-museum-tot-zover|website=ANWB|publisher=ANWB|accessdate=26 August 2015}} The museum is located in De Nieuwe Ooster, a memorial park in Amsterdam that includes a cemetery and crematorium.{{cite web|title=Museum|url=http://www.totzover.nl/index.php?page=museum|website=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover|publisher=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover|accessdate=26 August 2015}} The original building was designed as a caretaker’s residence by [[Adriaan Willem Weissman]] (1858–1923), who was a Dutch city architect best known for designing the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam|Stedelijk Museum]].{{cite web|title=Gebouw|url=http://www.totzover.nl/index.php?page=gebouw|website=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover|publisher=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover}} The collection includes items involved in funerary practices such as [[Death mask|funerary]] masks, [[casket]]s and [[urn]]s, as well as paintings and movie clips that demonstrate these funerary practices. The museum explores death and funerary practices along four themes: rituals, the body, mourning and remembrance, and [[memento mori]].{{cite web|title=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover|url=https://www.iamsterdam.com/nl/uit-in-amsterdam/zien-en-doen/musea-en-galeries/musea-in-amsterdam/nederlands-uitvaart-museum-tot-zover|website=Iamsterdam|publisher=Iamsterdam|accessdate=26 August 2015}} In addition to its collection, the Museum Tot Zover hosts temporary exhibitions of art and history. One of the museum’s exhibitions is “The Last Image,” which is a digital, online exhibition to which anyone can submit content.{{cite web|title=The Last Image|url=http://www.thelastimage.nl/|website=THE LAST IMAGE - TOT ZOVER|publisher=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover}} The premise of this ongoing exhibition is to explore the implications of photography and digital space in the process of death and dying.{{cite web|title=The Last Image|url=http://www.thelastimage.nl/|website=THE LAST IMAGE - NEDERLANDS UITVAART MUSEUM TOT ZOVER|publisher=Nederlands Uitvaart Museum Tot Zover|accessdate=26 August 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.totzover.nl/}} [[Category:Death customs]] [[Category:Museums established in 2007]] [[Category:Museums in Amsterdam]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2015}}
[[File:Oscar Spirescu (1874 - September 8, 1918) in 1916.jpg|thumb|Spirescu in 1916]] '''Oscar Spirescu''' (1874 – September 7, 1918) was a Romanian conductor, composer and pianist who took his own life in 1918.<ref name=obit/>
==Biography== Born in 1874, [[Bucharest]], Romania.<ref name=bio>{{cite news |author= |title=Oscar Spirescu Dies Suddenly |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=HO86AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA7-PA6&lpg=RA7-PA6&dq=Oscar+Spirescu&source=bl&ots=yhjnHDwULG&sig=DjDFElyIP2HaICZrt6pIdm7NAJk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kgrdU5SrMMqLyAT8poGQCw&ved=0CGMQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Oscar%20Spirescu&f=false |quote= |newspaper=[[Musical Courier]] |date= |accessdate=2014-08-02 }}</ref> He was married and had four children in Romania. He emigrated from Romania to the United States and married for a second time.<ref name=bio/>
In Romania, he was the conductor of the Romanian Opera Orchestra in Bucharest; in the US he became conductor of the Strand Symphony Orchestra at the [[Strand Theatre (Manhattan)|Strand Theatre]] in Manhattan.
He took his own life on September 7, 1918, with [[chloroform]] in [[Manhattan]].<ref name=obit>{{cite news |author= |title=Find Oscar Spirescu Dead In His Bed. Police Say Music Director of the Strand Killed Himself, But Friends Deny It |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/09/08/98270904.pdf |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=September 8, 1918 |accessdate=2014-08-02 }}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |author=David K. Frasier |encyclopedia =Suicide in the Entertainment Industry |title=Oscar Spirescu |year=2005 |publisher= |page=299 |quote= | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=97WJCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA299 |isbn= }}</ref> He died [[intestate]] and his estate was valued at $3,000.<ref>{{cite news |author= |agency= |title=Conductor Spirescu's Estate $3,000 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gNtFAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA14-PA17 |quote= |newspaper=[[Musical America]] |date=1919 |accessdate=2015-10-10 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spirescu, Oscar}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:Suicides in New York City]] [[Category:Drug-related suicides in New York (state)]] [[Category:Deaths from chloroform]] [[Category:Romanian emigrants to the United States]]

revision.text:
'''''Palliative Care Volunteers International''''' - [[non-profit organization]] providing assistance in [[hospice]] [[palliative care]] in different countries. Founded in 1994 and based in [[Texas]], United States.
The volunteers receive patients and visitors, answer the telephone, sit with patients, work at fund-raising, speak on behalf of the hospice and so on.
The organization takes part in the hospice care project in [[Vietnam]] with an annual budget of around US$35,000.
[[Category:Organizations established in 1994]] [[Category:Charities based in Texas]] [[Category:Foreign charities operating in Vietnam]] [[Category:Palliative care]]
{{US-philanthropy-org-stub}}

[[Image:Paul clarkin.jpg|frame|Paul Clarkin]] '''Paul Francis Clarkin''' (21 August 1950 – 22 July 2004) was a New Zealand [[polo]] player.
==Biography== Clarkin started playing polo in his early twenties. He was known internationally as 'Mr Polo'.<ref name="horseandhound">[http://www.horseandhound.co.uk/news/polo-player-killed-during-match/ Polo player killed during match], ''[[Horse & Hound]]'', February 09, 2013</ref> Together with his wife Chele, he ran a polo club.<ref name="horseandhound"/> He also compete as a show-jumper and eventer, and he was a keen huntsman.<ref name="horseandhound"/>
He was married to Chele Clarkin.<ref name="horseandhound"/><ref name="telegraph">Richard Savill and Gareth A. Davies, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1468004/Princes-mourn-polo-players-death.html Princes mourn polo player's death], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', July 28, 2004</ref> They had one daughter and two sons: *Emma Clarkin, who was studying law at the time of her death in a car accident at the age of 19. *[[John-Paul Clarkin]], a successful polo player who took over the running of Mystery Creek Polo Club in New Zealand after the death of his father and is married to [[Nina Clarkin|Nina]] (née Vestey) of an equally prestigious polo playing family based in Gloucestershire, England.<ref name="horseandhound"/> *[[Matthew Clarkin]] playing TOP 14 rugby in 2011 as captain of [[Union Bordeaux Bègles]] in [[France]].
He died playing polo in at the [[Cirencester Park Polo Club]] in [[Cirencester]], [[England]], after falling during a game in which he was reputedly "playing a blinder".<ref name="horseandhound"/><ref name="telegraph"/><ref>Anendra Singh, [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/hawkes-bay-today/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503460&objectid=11087235 Clarkin clan taking polo in their stride], ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'', 12 January 2013</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clarkin, Paul}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:New Zealand polo players]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Sport deaths in England]]
{{NewZealand-sport-bio-stub}}
